>>Nikesh Arora: So I'm sure all of you have
lots of interesting questions, and part of

13.text:
it is that as I was reading up, trying to
figure out what question to ask, there are

16.text:
so many things we could talk about that you
would have to miss your train. So we're not

19.text:
going to do that.
>>George Osborne Yeah. No, we won't.

21.text:
>>Nikesh Arora: All these people in this room
are leaders. They all make decisions every

26.text:
morning and they get held accountable for
their decisions very soon after. And you've

31.text:
heralded a lot of change in the last one year,
lots of different things.

35.text:
How would you rate your decisions and how
would you think of yourself after one year,

41.text:
if you were these people holding us accountable?
>>George Osborne: Well, the great thing about

45.text:
my job is everyone else rates my decision
so I don't have to do it myself.

48.text:
[Laughter]
>>George Osborne: Look, I think we've -- I

53.text:
would say a couple of things.
I mean, first of all, I think we've achieved

55.text:
a lot in the last year. I mean, particularly
given that we are a coalition government,

59.text:
given that we didn't have a majority in the
Parliament, no one party had a majority in

63.text:
the Parliament, and really I think the last
year has shown that that has not proved to

67.text:
be a hindrance to taking some really ambitious
reforms. Not just on the economy, but also

73.text:
in public services, education reform, higher
education reform, you know, where I think

78.text:
we took some very necessary decisions to ensure
it was properly funded, and police reform.

84.text:
And of course health reform which, you know,
we're now engaged in a process of improving.

89.text:
But, you know, these are big changes.
And then some of the things I highlighted

92.text:
today, I did so because in amongst the big
arrangements, a lot of those sorts of things

97.text:
which we've spent quite a lot of time trying
to get right and we think is quite original

101.text:
to our government have not, for understandable
reasons, got much attention.

106.text:
So, yeah, I think we've shown we're a strong
government taking difficult decisions, we

112.text:
believe, in the national interest. It's up
to you lot to decide whether we've done a

117.text:
good job or not.
>>Nikesh Arora: I think these changes are

119.text:
very exciting. A lot of the stuff that you're
done and you're proposing are going to be

121.text:
very interesting things for all of us to watch
out for.

126.text:
You alluded to all these people in the room.
You said, you know, you want to see how these

129.text:
people are making an impact. What else could
people in this room be doing, in addition

133.text:
to all the things you've highlighted, to support
some of these changes and some of these ideas

137.text:
you've brought forward?
>>George Osborne: Well, I'd just say I think

139.text:
if you look at many of the companies represented
here, and the individuals here, there is a

143.text:
massive opportunity when you open up a sector
which currently accounts for around 48% of

149.text:
the national income to the private sector
to make use of the data that it produces.

156.text:
When you think of the amount of data produced
by -- you know, out of a city like London,

160.text:
the transport data, the social data, the crime
data and so on, and put that to commercial

166.text:
use to help individuals find out more about
the city they live in, get the services they

172.text:
want, as well as the job that the government
has in providing free information as we've

176.text:
done through crime mapping, I think is just
an enormous economic opportunity and I would

181.text:
urge people to get in there, get stuck in.
I think the scope for new applications, new

188.text:
uses of that data, is enormous.
>>Nikesh Arora: People, if you have questions,

193.text:
please feel free because we have very few
scarce minutes with George.

197.text:
>>George Osborne: I should have explained
I'm going to a meeting of European finance

200.text:
ministers in Brussels so I've got to get the
train. Not everyone is going to be there,

206.text:
>>George Osborne: -- I'm going to make sure
I am.

210.text:
[Laughter]
>>Nikesh Arora: Do you have a question?

214.text:
>>Tim Lefroy>>> Thanks, Nikesh. Sorry. Excuse
me.

217.text:
Mr. Osborne, Tim Lefroy from the Advertising
Association.

222.text:
I found that really inspirational, the package
of measures that would make the U.K. attractive

231.text:
to international business leaders here.
And it's very true that government's doing

236.text:
a huge amount.
Do you think you've been as good at actually

241.text:
telling people about that and actually getting
the message out, especially what you're doing

246.text:
for business in the U.K. and attracting inward
investment?

249.text:
>>George Osborne: I think the truth is -- and
I don't complain about it, and for very understandable

253.text:
reasons -- a lot of international attention
and domestic attention has focused in Britain

258.text:
on our public expenditure savings and the
decisions we're taking to reduce this 10%

264.text:
budget deficit, and therefore, some of the
other things we're doing have not received

269.text:
the same amount of attention.
Now, that is -- as I say, I'm not complaining

272.text:
about that. I think that's where the political
argument is, that's where the international

277.text:
interest in.
But on business more generally, we are also

281.text:
taking a pretty aggressive approach to making
the U.K. a more competitive place to do business,

285.text:
aggressive reductions in corporation tax from
28% to 26% this year, down to 23% by the end

292.text:
of this Parliament. I mean, that is something
that the rest of the world is beginning to

296.text:
notice: Look what the U.K. is doing.
And a lot of the entrepreneurial tax breaks

301.text:
as well.
So add into that this whole agenda, which

307.text:
there is a dedicated team right in the heart
of 10 Downing Street -- this is not peripheral

312.text:
to the government. For those of you who know
the government, you will know that the individuals

316.text:
involved in this are right literally in the
next-door office to the prime minister and

322.text:
we all try to be, for a large advanced economy,
the first that really embraces the governing

330.text:
potential, the governance potential, as well,
of the Internet and the information opportunities

337.text:
that exist.
>>Nikesh Arora: Thank you. Please.

344.text:
>>Jon Fredrik Baksaas: Thank you. My name
is Jon Fredrik Baksaas from TeleNor in Norway.

352.text:
I agree with the previous speaker here that
your speech was very optimistic in its term

359.text:
on what it's going to deliver, but one question
to you.

363.text:
When you are sort of putting digital means
into the government processes the way you

368.text:
were discussing here, how do you get the string
of people involved in the old processes to

373.text:
sort of embrace it in the same way as you
have done as government? And is it because

381.text:
of the crisis that you might get people to
understand that it is a necessity to spend

387.text:
government funds better and to increase the
efficiency there?

391.text:
Are these factors that play in to the ability
to get this done?

395.text:
>>George Osborne: I think that helps.
I mean, look, first of all, government, by

399.text:
its nature, has been for, you know, hundreds
of years -- probably since the creation first

405.text:
of government, whenever it was several thousand
years ago -- is hierarchical, it is bureaucratic,

413.text:
and it's very large. I mean, I think sometimes
it's worth remembering the scale of some of

418.text:
the government departments in the U.K., let
alone, you know, larger countries who have

422.text:
larger populations.
So the health service employs 1.4 million

426.text:
people directly and that is an enormous organization.
And you're trying to make it less hierarchical,

436.text:
trying to empower the service deliverers,
the professionals who actually work in public

441.text:
service as well as the users, is a big challenge,
but I think actually the technology provides

446.text:
a powerful tool for doing that.
You need to have the capability of the Internet

454.text:
to allow patients to look at different hospitals
and compare different performances rather

460.text:
than having to go to the public library and
go through a book.

464.text:
So I think there is an opportunity there.
I think second -- you alluded to this -- I

468.text:
think the truth is this: That, you know, although
there is a debate about the pace of deficit

473.text:
reduction in the U.K. between the late body
and the coalition government, the truth is

480.text:
that everybody has got to understand -- and
I think everyone does understand -- there

485.text:
is going to be a reduction in this deficit
over the next few years, and that the public

491.text:
services are not going to have the resources
that they once did, or at least the annual

496.text:
increases that they once did.
And so that is forcing people in the public

499.text:
services to think about how you deliver education
or healthcare in a more efficient way or get

505.text:
better value for money.
And when the money was pouring in with big

508.text:
annual increases, that was not a primary concern,
understandably, because they wanted -- you

513.text:
know, they were more interested in how they
were going to spend the additional money.

516.text:
So I think there is a greater focus and that
is forcing that thinking.

520.text:
>>Nikesh Arora: Well, George, I know you have
to run. Thank you very much for kicking us

524.text:
off. Thank you very much for your inspirational
words.
